intro: Chrysanthemum chamomilla, commonly known as German chamomile, is a flowering plant native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its daisy-like flowers with white petals and a yellow center. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, aromatic flowers that bloom in the summer months. Its leaves are finely divided and covered in a soft, downy texture, while the flowers are used in herbal teas and traditional medicine for their calming properties. The essential oil extracted from its flowers contains compounds like alpha-bisabolol and chamazulene, which contribute to its anti-inflammatory and soothing effects.
